    1. Nowadays, watching TV is one of the most important children'sleisure activities.
    2. However, whether it brings more than good is a controversialissue.
    3. My view is that too much time spent on it surely has negativeimpacts on kids and parents should filter out the inappropriate programsand channels for them.
    4. First, it is obvious that, with the rapid development of science andtechnology, TV shows are designed so vivid and attractive that not onlykids but even adults are much easier to get addicted to them.
    5. This means that when children spend more time sitting in front ofscreen, they are isolated from the real world. They do not have enoughtime to socialize or to engage in outdoor activities which are crucialfor their for their physical growth.
    6. Also, their eyesight will be weakened by staring at the screen fortoo long.
    7. Moreover, questionable contents on TV will have negative effects onchildren since their minds are impressionable.
    8. For example, the fact that many developing countries including Chinalack a TV program rating system means that children are more easilyexposed to indecent TV scenes.
    9. So, TV is not always a good one in the sense that parents reallycannot control what comes on the screen.
    10. It is also true that there are many educational and inspirational TVshows, such as Disney cartoons which enable kids to have fun in thelearning process, facilitate their intellectual development and helpthem caring, sharing, courage, honesty and other virtues from an earlyage.
    11. These benefits of TV on a child's education cannot be denied.
    12. In sum, spending a long time watching TV is harmful and parentsshould either follow TV rating guidelines or carefully choose theprograms for children.

These two bar graphs illustrates the changes of USAmarriage and divorce rates between 1970 and 2000, and the marital statusof adult Americans in two of the years.

According to the first graph, there were 2.5mmarriages in both 1970 and 1980, and then decreased gradually during thenext two decades, reaching to 2m in 2000. By comparison, the number ofdivorces first increased from 1m in 1970 to around 1.4m in 1980 and thenslowly declined back to 1m in 2000.

As can be seen from the second bar graph, thepercentage of married American adults dropped by more than 10%, from 70%in 1970 to less than 60% in 2000. Meanwhile, the percentage of adultAmerican who were never married increased from about 15% in 1970 to 20%in 2000, and despite still less than 10%, the proportion of divorcedadults significantly went up from 1970 to 2000. Moreover, the percentageof the widowed in 1970 and 2000 accounted for less than 10%respectively, and showed a slight drop.

Overall, it is clear that marital status of adultAmericans in 2000 was not as optimistic as that of three decadesago.

These graphs illustrate the change of people'seating habits between 1970 and 2000.

According to the four pie charts, the percentage ofthe family's food budget spent on restaurant meals steadilyincreased during this period. Just 10 percent of the foodbudget was spent on restaurant meals in 1970, and 15 percent in 1980.That percentage more than doubled in 1990, to 35 percent, and rose againin 2000 to 50 percent.

As can be seen from the following line graph,families ate the same number of meals at fast food and sit-downrestaurants, 20 meals in 1970. In 1980, families ate slightly morefrequently at sit-down restaurants. However, at the end of 1980's,the popularity of the fast food caught up with that of the sit-downrestaurants, and families ate about 40 meals at both fast food andsit-down restaurants per year. From then on, the number fast foodmeals increased much more dramatically to 90 meals in 2000, nearlydoubling the number of meals they ate at sit-downrestaurants.

Overall, it is clear that people spent more andmore money on restaurant meals and fast food became animportant option when families chose to eat out.

[!Note] é¢˜ç›®

These two diagrams illustrate the main reasons ofland degradation in the world and its different impacts on three areasduring the 1990s.

According to the first pie chart, livestock'sover-grazing was the biggest factor leading to the barren land,accounting for the 35%. This was followed by deforestation andover-cultivation, representing 30% and 28% respectively. Otherunidentified reasons made up the left proportion, 7%collectively.

As can be seen from the second table whichhighlights the different situations in the three regions: NorthAmerica, Europe, and Oceania, Europe was affected most seriously and 23%of land there turned into less productive, largely caused bydeforestation (9.8%). Moreover, 13% of agricultural land in Oceaniabecame worse, mainly due to over-grazing which alone contributed11.3%. By comparison, the condition in North America wasmuch better and only 5% of total land degraded. Over-cultivation wasthe major trigger there, providing 3.3%.

Overall, it is clear that at least 93% of farmlanddegradation worldwide was related to human activities in 1990 s andalthough the dominant cause varies in different continents, Europesuffered most during that period.

    13. Meanwhile, local authorities and organizations must[[shoulder]] their responsibility to develop a low carbon economy at themacro level.
    14. Only by doing so can we assure that we will hand thisbeautiful planet to our next generation, and the next generationthereafter.

    1. Nowadays, an increasing number of people are concernedabout animal protection and animal rights.
    2. However, whether we should utilize animals forhuman purposes has recently caused a heateddebate.

    5. This means that mankind uses animals for its ownbenefit, which is consistent with natural law.
    6. So it is hard to say that we are doing wrong byexploiting animals for our interests.
    7. Moreover, it is unrealistic to ban using animalssince the history of human civilization is entwined with thehistory of the ways we have learned to manipulate animalresources.

    9. If using animals were prohibited, we would firstly close thousandsof restaurants' franchises around the world and become vegetarians.
    10. This is not to say that it is always right forpeople to use animals for any purpose whatsoever.
    11. There are, of course, some behaviors that peoplehunt wild animals just for fun and kill rare animals for their expensivefurs, which are not only cruel and unnecessary, but actually againstlong-term interests of human race.
    12. Humans should shoulder their responsibilities of maintaining thediversity of wild animals and the balance of ecosystem.
    13. In sum, using animals rationally for the benefit ofhumans is justified.
    14. Meanwhile, some behaviors that are harmful to bothanimals and humans have to be prohibited.
    15. Only by doing so can we assure that our nextgeneration will also benefit from animal resource.

    14. Meanwhile, governments must [[shoulder]] theirresponsibility to ensure a fair distribution of wealth in society.
    15. Only by doing so can we believe that technologywill serve as a catalyst for creating social wealth.

    2. äº¤ä»£è¾©è®ºè¯é¢˜ï¼šSome people do not like changes, mainly becausechanges bring unfamiliarity, which means the possibility of makingmistakes; others, however, believe change is always a good thing.
    3. è¡¨è¾¾å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šMy view is that the majority of changes lead topositive results, and we should adapt and keep pace with them.
    4. ç¬¬ä¸€è®ºæ®ï¼Œä¸­å¿ƒå¥ï¼šFirst, it is obvious that change, [[per se]] isthe only thing that never changes in the universe.
    5. è¿›ä¸€æ­¥å…·ä½“é˜è¿°ç†ç”±ï¼Œæ‹“å±•ï¼šThis means that although we may avoid ordeny some changes that could occur, we cannot stop the whole world fromchanging.
    6. æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œè§‚ç‚¹æˆç«‹ï¼šSo, it is wiser to face the reality, appreciatethese changes, and try to make the most of them.
    7. ç¬¬äºŒè®ºæ®ï¼Œä¸­å¿ƒå¥ï¼šMoreover, some changes like scientificinnovations, technological inventions, and new academic theories, aredriving forces behind social progress.
    8. ä¸¾ä¾‹ï¼Œç»å…¸ä¸ªä¾‹æˆ–æ’æ¯”ä¾‹è¯ï¼šFor example, modern information technologyhas already changed the world and the way people work, relax,communicate, and even receive education.
    9. ä¾‹è¯è§£é‡Šè¯´æ˜ï¼šIt has also improved the productivity of manyindustries as well as our living standard.
    10. è®¨è®ºåæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šThis is not to say that any changes end well.
    11. åæ–¹è®ºæ®ï¼šWhen we enjoy the benefits of changes, we sometimes losemore important things.
    12. é©³æ–¥åæ–¹æˆ–éƒ¨åˆ†åŒæ„åæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šIndeed, we have seen invaluabletraditional culture fade away, both people and animals have sufferedfrom climate change, and we are trying our best to protect theenvironment and ecosystem from negative changes.
    13. é‡ç”³å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šIn summary, most changes are an inevitable fact oflife and we had better develop an active attitude towards them.
    14. ä¸èƒ½å¿½è§†åæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼š
    15. æ€æƒ³ç«‹æ„æå‡ï¼šMeanwhile though, we have to preserve what we believeis valuable.

  3. æ­£æ–‡ï¼š
    1. ã€å¼•å…¥èƒŒæ™¯ã€‘Universities are one of the most important institutionsin modern society.
    2. ã€äº¤ä»£è¾©è®ºè¯é¢˜ã€‘ [[Post-secondary]] education provides both generalskills and knowledge and sometimes job-specific training. But which ofthese two should be the main focus?
    3. ã€è¡¨è¾¾å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ã€‘While many people might think the focus should onlybe "jobs", I believe universities play a larger social role.
    4. ã€ç¬¬ä¸€è®ºæ®ã€‘Let us consider that we live in an information age. If astudent wants to learn about accounting or history or other job-specificinformation, they do not need to sit in a classroom to get it.
    5. ã€è¿›ä¸€æ­¥å…·ä½“é˜è¿°ç†ç”±ï¼Œæ‰©å±•ã€‘Nowadays, anyone can get information andknowledge online and can learn on their own.
    6. ã€æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œè§‚ç‚¹æˆç«‹ã€‘So surely universities aren't needed for thispurpose.
    7. ã€ç¬¬äºŒè®ºæ®ï¼Œä¸­å¿ƒå¥ã€‘Instead, what universities should focus on isdeveloping [[critical thinking]].
    8. ã€è¿›ä¸€æ­¥å…·ä½“é˜è¿°ç†ç”±ï¼Œæ‰©å±•ã€‘Anyone can memorize facts andget on-job training, but not everyone can think and analyze.This is a far more important skill in the real world.
    9. ã€æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œè§‚ç‚¹æˆç«‹ã€‘To be able to process information, understand itand use it, these are the skills our universities should focus onbuilding.
    10. ã€è®¨è®ºåæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ã€‘That is not say that universities should not pay anyattention to the workplace.
    11. ã€åæ–¹è®ºæ®ã€‘Of course all graduates want to find good work.
    12. ã€é©³æ–¥åæ–¹ã€‘But if you ask most people in the workplace today, theywill tell you that the specific skills required for their jobs werelearned on-site. And if you ask most employers what they are looking forin employees, they will tell you that it is a mind that can "[[thinkoutside of the box]]."
    13. ã€é‡ç”³å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ã€‘So while universities play a role intraining people for the [[workforce]], they primarily function as aplace for training the mind.ï¼ˆå¥½å¥ï¼‰
    14. ã€æ€æƒ³ç«‹æ„æå‡ã€‘What most companies and workforces need arenot robots, but creative people who can contribute ideas.(å¥½å¥)Universities should be the driving force in nurturing such people.

9.1.2 æ•™è‚²æ–¹æ³•

  1. è€ƒé¢˜
  2. æçº²
    1. åˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ•™è‚²ç±»
    2. è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šè¿œç¨‹æ•™è‚²å’Œä¼ ç»Ÿæ•™è‚²å„æœ‰ä¼˜åŠ¿, åº”ç»“åˆåº”ç”¨ã€‚
      1. åŸå›  1ï¼šæ•™å¸ˆæˆè¯¾çš„ä¼˜åŠ¿ï¼›
      2. åŸå›  2ï¼šè¿œç¨‹æ•™å­¦çš„å¥½å¤„ï¼›

  3. æ­£æ–‡
    1. å¼•å…¥èƒŒæ™¯ï¼šDistance learning is a relatively recent phenomenon andconsequently it is somewhat controversial.
    2. äº¤ä»£è¾©è®ºè¯é¢˜ï¼šWith good reason, many people question whethertechnology can really change how we can learn. Others, however, make aconvincing argument that classroom-based learning has itslimitations.
    3. è¡¨è¾¾å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šConsidering both sides, it is clear that thereis value in both approaches.
    4. ç¬¬ä¸€è®ºæ®ï¼šLet us first consider the pros of traditional,classroom-based learning.
    5. è¿›ä¸€æ­¥å…·ä½“é˜è¿°ç†ç”±ï¼Œæ‹“å±•ï¼šFrom the time of the ancient Greeks andChinese and perhaps before, we have clung to the idea of a "teacher",one who shares his / her wisdom and expertise. This model has beentested and survived the ages. Teachers not only can shareknowledge, but they can access, correct and motivatestudents.
    6. æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œè§‚ç‚¹æˆç«‹ï¼šTruly there is great value in this.
    7. ç¬¬äºŒè®ºæ®ï¼šThat said, remote learning also has its own upside.
    8. ä¸¾ä¾‹ï¼Œç»å…¸ä¸ªä¾‹æˆ–æ’æ¯”ä¾‹è¯ï¼šConsider, for example, students who livein remote areas without roads or funds to pay for tuition to attend aschool far away. An Internet connection solves this.
    9. æ’æ¯”ä¾‹è¯ï¼šAlso, there is something to be said for students beingmore independent learners, and online learning develops this skill.
    10. è®¨è®ºåæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šSo the question really is not "Which one?" butrather, "How we can combine both?"
    11. åæ–¹è®ºæ®ï¼šIt seems perfectly reasonable that students attend someclasses in person, but also use the web to communicate with otherstudents and professors as well as research various topics.
    12. é©³æ–¥åæ–¹æˆ–éƒ¨åˆ†åŒæ„åæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šCountries and societies need to assesswhich approach and balance works best for them.
    13. é‡ç”³å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šSo while we should harness the potential ofnew technology that makes remote learning possible, we should notneglect the importance of traditional learning.
    14. æ€æƒ³ç«‹æ„æå‡ï¼šStudents without teachers will surely be lost;but students who simply rely on teachers for knowledge are not reallylearning.
